awd_titl_txt: Triboelectric Nanogenerator Ion Mobility-Mass Spectrometry for Studying Cultural Heritage Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
Daniel Vallejo is awarded a FY21 Mathematical and Physical Sciences Ascending Postdoctoral Research (NSF MPS-Ascend) Fellowship to conduct a program of research and activities related to broadening participation by groups underrepresented in Chemistry at Georgia Tech.  The project being performed by Daniel Vallejo, entitled Triboelectric Nanogenerator Ion Mobility-Mass Spectrometry for Studying Cultural Heritage Materials, is to be conducted under the guidance of mentoring scientist Facundo M. Fernández.  This project is supported by the Office of Multidisciplinary Activities in the Mathematical and Physical Sciences Directorate.

The research project examines a new approach for analyzing the chemical constituents of cultural heritage materials based on the coupling of a triboelectric nanogenerator (TENG) ion source with ion mobility-mass spectrometry (IM-MS). The approach minimizes sample consumption compared with traditional mass-selective methods of analysis, while also distinguishing structural differences of protein binding agents in paints and other cultural heritage materials that could not be identified using mass spectrometry alone. The research plan includes a systematic characterization of protein structure and stability in simulated samples, as well as development of a new database for compiling data that are relevant to the community. The broader impacts of the project include the importance of cultural heritage materials and the likelihood that studying these materials will broaden participation in STEM research by engaging students from diverse backgrounds. Activities supported by this project also bring together scientists and conservators at the intersection of science and cultural heritage research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
In 2023, the 100 most popular museums in the world received an estimated 175 million visitors combined. The top 10 art museums have 11 million objects collectively, and it is the mission of these museums to protect these objects for future generations to learn about their own and other societies cultural heritage. Art, like all objects is composed of atoms and molecules that may undergo reactions. In the short term the majority of these reactions have no effect, but as the object ages or becomes exposed to extreme conditions (e.g. smoke, fires, liquids, physical damage, etc.) they can become damaged not only visually with the naked eye, but at the molecular level.

When this damage occurs, we have many ways to measure the changes in the art material. However, art material that is created from biological materials like animal products (e.g. eggs, skin, milk, etc.) remain understudied. A limitation to studying these materials is the ultra-precious nature of the samples that limits the number of experiments that can be done. Therefore, there is a need to develop new chemical analysis techniques that can answer multiple scientific questions simultaneously while requiring the smallest amount of sample possible.

Throughout my 3 years addressing this challenge I developed a novel method to analyze samples relevant to cultural heritage research. This method involves triboelectric nanogenerators (TENG) that take advantage of static electricity to introduce the samples to our scientific instruments. Combined with these state-of-the-art instruments we are able to accurately measure the shape, size, and charge of the molecules relevant to these objects and determine changes in structural stability. We can do this with a single drop of sample measuring 1 microliter and with femtomole sensitivity which is amenable with the requirements for the ultra-precious materials being measured. We have employed this method primarily towards the analysis of egg-based and milk-based proteins which are commonly found in tempera paintings, a common medium prior to the 15th century before it was replaced by oil paints. We have also studied gums which are commonly found in binder mediums such as glues and are notoriously challenging to identify accurately.

We have also taken into consideration the financial restraints smaller cultural heritage institutions may have. When starting this project, the average build cost for the TENG device was close to $10,000 and was approximately the size of a standard U.S. refrigerator, and the cost and size was a notable concern for conservation scientists. With this feedback we not only reduced the cost of the TENG device by 94% to $600 dollars, but we also reduced the size in volume by over 30-times to approximately the size of a standard microwave. Additionally, we produced a series of instructional YouTube videos ensuring that those interested in building their own TENG device may do so wherever and whenever they like.

Lastly, the most notable challenges after data acquisition is data analysis. The art materials may be ultra-precious or rare meaning there is no reference dataset. Sometimes a reference dataset may be generated if the material is easily accessible, but often this is not the case. We have spent considerable time in the cultural heritage community discussing this topic, and there remains a strong interest in the development of a cultural heritage focused database for scientific measurements. Together, these outcomes have enriched the cultural heritage research field and have highlighted exciting new research areas to be explored in the future for the technology developed in this project, as well as more broadly by recognizing the significance of proteins and other biological molecules as art materials.

The broader impact for my solicitation was to develop community engagement for traditionally underrepresented minority (URM) groups in STEM fields. I achieved this in several ways, with one primary mechanism being my engagement with Alliance for Graduate Education and the Professoriate (AGEP) program. Through AGEP I was able to engage with URM at every level of their academic process (undergraduate, graduate, postdoctoral, faculty, administrators, etc.), and engage in dialogues on improving engagement at the participating universities. Additionally, I became a postdoctoral mentor through the program. The mentoring strategies learned have been beneficial to the 10 graduate students I have either mentored or supervised. I additionally engaged with K-12 students at annual science fairs as a judge where engage their interest in science through discussing their projects, asking questions about their interest in science, and answering questions about a career in science. Lastly, I initiated a collaboration to highlight postdoctoral researchers who are often an underserved population at research institutions despite being the backbone for academic research progress. We highlighted several postdocs from diverse backgrounds, and highlighted what it meant to be a postdoc, how they’ve overcome challenges, and celebrating the postdoctoral community. The project received widespread praise and reached over 15,000 social media accounts

 


Last Modified: 07/26/2024
Modified by: Daniel D Vallejo
